Name: Mrs. Joseph A. Smiley
Address: Robart, Sask.
Birthplace: Wolfville, Nova Scotia

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1913
   Where did you set up housekeeping? On the farm, 10 mi. N. of Robart
   Where had you been living before that? North Dakota
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Four
   How far was it to your nearest store? 1913 - 46 miles; 1914 - 12 mi
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a month
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, salt, yeast, sugar, tea, salt pork, dried peaches & peaches

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. sacks
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
   How much did you use Graham flour? Very little
   Whole wheat flour? None
   Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 4.5 mi., what year? 1914
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use? I think around 60 or 70¢
   Cornmeal? Yes, Whole wheat? Farina? Yes
   Other? Oatmeal
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Boiled it whole
   How did you grind it? Sometimes in the coffee mill

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Once my husband was away working, one night he came home. I said "we are almost out of coal & groceries." So he planned to go to town next morning for them but in the morning there was a raging blizzard on so the first day he could not get to the barn. The next two days were almost as bad but by tying a string to the house so he could get back he managed to get to the barn. During those three days we had nothing to eat but bread, water and potatoes without salt so on the fourth day when he came home from town, believe me we had a feed! Had to burn the hay/rack to keep warm.
Now we got food wrapped in allspice.

Once my husband was away working one night he came home and said we are almost out of vital supplies. So he planned to go to town next morning for them but in the morning there was a raging blizzard and so the first day he could not get to the town. The next two days were almost as bad but by Tuesday a string to the farm. During those three days we had nothing to eat but bread. Three days we had potatoes without salt so on the fourth day when he came home from town, believe me we had a feast. Glad to have the boys back to keep warm.
